rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning about spending one-on-one time with your child. 

Spending dedicated, special time with your child will make them feel valued and loved.
It will also build trust and respect, and support their learning.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we are learning about spending one-on-one time with your child. 

Spending dedicated, special time with your child will make them feel valued and loved.
It will also build trust and respect, and support their learning.

media_title.eng: How will it help me and my family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings!

It turns out that our children don’t need lots of gifts. The best gift we can give them is to spend time with them.

Spending time together (just the two of you) will help you to understand your child better and help them to learn new things.

Having this time together with your child will feel special because it will help them feel loved and valued. And that will make everything easier at home!

rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings!

It turns out that our children don’t need lots of gifts. The best gift we can give them is to spend time with them.

Spending time together (just the two of you) will help you to understand your child better and help them to learn new things.

Having this time together with your child will feel special because it will help them feel loved and valued. And that will make everything easier at home!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
One-on-one time can be fun for both of you!

Let’s look at how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name do this!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
One-on-one time can be fun for both of you!

Let’s look at how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name do this!

character_1_text.eng: I see you are playing quietly with those building blocks with concentration, Faisal.

rows.character_1_text: I see you are playing quietly with those building blocks with concentration, Faisal.
Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those building blocks.

character_1_text.eng: Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those building blocks.

rows.character_1_text: This enclosure is a cat house. It will keep your cat safe!

character_1_text.eng: This enclosure is a cat house. It will keep your cat safe!

character_2_text.eng: Now you can help make a house for you and me to sleep in.

rows.character_2_text: Now you can help make a house for you and me to sleep in.

rows.character_1_text: This house is going to keep us both safe and happy. You are such a good builder, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name.

character_1_text.eng: This house is going to keep us both safe and happy. You are such a good builder, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s reflect on what we saw.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on what we saw.

quiz_1_question.eng: How does @data.characters.f3_uncle.name show @data.characters.f3_son_4.name that he is focusing on him?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Yes, he does! 

The simple act of calling @data.characters.f3_son_4.name by his name and describing what he is doing helps him feel valued and seen.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: He invites @data.characters.f3_son_4.name to come and play with him.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: False. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name is able to get down on the same level as @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. This helps @data.characters.f3_son_4.name know that his uncle is paying attention to playing with him.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: He is trying to help build the house while he is playing with @data.characters.f3_uncle.name.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: False. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name gets down on @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s level, looks at him and uses him name so @data.characters.f3_son_4.name knows that @data.characters.f3_uncle.name is present and paying attention to him.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: He tells @data.characters.f3_son_4.name how to build a house.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: No, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name doesn’t dictate what they will do, but describes what @data.characters.f3_son_4.name is doing. This is an important part of child-led play..

quiz_1_option_5_text.eng: He notices and praises what @data.characters.f3_son_4.name does.

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Yes, he does all these things! This way, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name knows that @data.characters.f3_uncle.name really cares about him.

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Probably not! Spending one-on-one time has a big positive impact on how your child feels. He probably feels happy about being close to his uncle!

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: In a good way! Spending one-on-one time will make your child feel loved!

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: That is right. Spending one-on-one time has a big positive impact on how your child feels.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: Probably not. Spending one-on-one time is an opportunity to appreciate the amazing things your child can do!

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: That is right. Spending one-on-one Time has a big positive impact on how your child feels.

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng: Yes! Spending time with our children helps us to connect with them. We can enjoy time together without also trying to do chores or work.

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Probably not. Spending special time with our children helps us to feel close to them without having to worry about work or chores.

quiz_3_feedback_3.eng: Probably not. Spending time with our children is relaxing because we are able to enjoy time together without it feeling like work.

rows.text_2:
**One-on-one time helps your child feel important, valued, and loved**
- The more positive time you spend with your child, the less negative time you will spend with your child. 
- It is what you do at home that makes the difference!

**Do it every day**
- Set aside a specific time each day to spend one-on-one time with your child (at least 5 minutes—more is better!). 
- Choose a time when you won’t be interrupted and when your child does not have something else they want to do, like watching TV or playing with their tablet.  
- Turn off the TV, put away mobile phones and tablets. 
- Tell your child you would like to spend one-on-one time and that they can choose what to do. 
**Make sure your child knows you are watching them**
- Sit close to your child and give them your full attention. 
- Turn your body towards them or sit beside them. 
- Get down to your child’s level. 
- Look at your child and notice what s/he is doing. 
- Use your child’s name when you speak to him or her. 

**Follow their lead**
- Let your child take the lead during one-on-one time. 
- Accept what your child wants to do as long as it is a safe activity. 
- Children need to do things in their own time. Let things go at your child’s pace. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. 
- You can watch your child play or you can try different activities together.

**Use words to describe what your child is doing**
- Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening! 
- Your child will learn a lot from what you say and do. 

**Praise** 
- Remember this is the child's game. Can you think how you have felt recently when someone has been critical of you? 
- There is no right or wrong in play, and within reason, what your child chooses to play is right for them. 
- Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.

**Give as few instructions or directions as possible.**
- Of course, you have to take action if your child does something that he or she is not allowed to do, such as ignoring an agreed house rule, or wants to do something dangerous (like playing with matches)
-However, generally when you are spending one-on-one time with your child, s/he or she should lead the activity. 
- Also, try not to ask questions. 

**Give just enough help so it feels like their achievement.**
- Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. 
- If they ask what to do, turn the question back by asking what they could do or think that they might do next. 
- For children who do not have self-confidence, it is particularly important that they do not get directions from adults all the time.

**You are in charge**
- You must decide when the session finishes. 
- Give your child a “Transition Warning” when there is one minute remaining in one-on-one time.

text_2.eng:
**One-on-one time helps your child feel important, valued, and loved**
- The more positive time you spend with your child, the less negative time you will spend with your child. 
- It is what you do at home that makes the difference!

**Do it every day**
- Set aside a specific time each day to spend one-on-one time with your child (at least 5 minutes—more is better!). 
- Choose a time when you won’t be interrupted and when your child does not have something else they want to do, like watching TV or playing with their tablet.  
- Turn off the TV, put away mobile phones and tablets. 
- Tell your child you would like to spend one-on-one time and that they can choose what to do. 
**Make sure your child knows you are watching them**
- Sit close to your child and give them your full attention. 
- Turn your body towards them or sit beside them. 
- Get down to your child’s level. 
- Look at your child and notice what s/he is doing. 
- Use your child’s name when you speak to him or her. 

**Follow their lead**
- Let your child take the lead during one-on-one time. 
- Accept what your child wants to do as long as it is a safe activity. 
- Children need to do things in their own time. Let things go at your child’s pace. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. 
- You can watch your child play or you can try different activities together.

**Use words to describe what your child is doing**
- Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening! 
- Your child will learn a lot from what you say and do. 

**Praise** 
- Remember this is the child's game. Can you think how you have felt recently when someone has been critical of you? 
- There is no right or wrong in play, and within reason, what your child chooses to play is right for them. 
- Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.

**Give as few instructions or directions as possible.**
- Of course, you have to take action if your child does something that he or she is not allowed to do, such as ignoring an agreed house rule, or wants to do something dangerous (like playing with matches)
-However, generally when you are spending one-on-one time with your child, s/he or she should lead the activity. 
- Also, try not to ask questions. 

**Give just enough help so it feels like their achievement.**
- Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. 
- If they ask what to do, turn the question back by asking what they could do or think that they might do next.

**You are in charge**
- You must decide when the session finishes. 
- Give your child a “Transition Warning” when there is one minute remaining in one-on-one time.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Ready to try it out? 

Your home activity is to spend 5 minutes (or more) of one-on-one time with your child, every day.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Ready to try it out? 

Your home activity is to spend 5 minutes (or more) of one-on-one time with your child, every day.

quiz_1_question.eng: Where will you spend one-on-one time with your child?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Great choice! Spending time at the beach is a wonderful way to spend one-on-one time with your child and enjoy some fresh air together.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Perfect! Home is full of opportunities for quality time, whether it's playing, reading, or just relaxing together.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: While going to school or daycare

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Excellent idea! The journey to school or daycare can be a special time to connect with your child.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Wonderful! No matter where you choose, spending one-on-one time with your child is what truly matters.

quiz_2_question.eng: When will you spend one-on-one time with your child?

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: In the morning before starting the day

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Great start! Spending time with your child in the morning can set a positive tone for the rest of the day.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Perfect! After school or daycare is a great time to reconnect with your child

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Wonderful! Sharing a meal together is a special way to bond and enjoy each other's company

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: Lovely choice! Bedtime is a calming time to connect, share stories, and end the day on a warm note.

quiz_2_option_5_text.eng: During a commute (e.g., driving to school or an activity)

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: Excellent idea! Commutes are a valuable opportunity to chat and spend meaningful time together

quiz_2_feedback_6.eng: Fantastic! Whatever time you choose, making it a regular part of your routine ensures meaningful one-on-one time with your child.

quiz_3_question.eng: How will you spend one-on-one time with your child today?

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng:
Great idea!

Do you ever feel like you have NO TIME and are exhausted? We’ve all been there! Try to think of ways to make daily activities fun together.

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng:
Great idea!

Do you ever feel like you have NO TIME and are exhausted? We’ve all been there! Try to think of ways to make daily activities fun together.

quiz_3_feedback_3.eng:
Great idea!

Do you ever feel like you have NO TIME and are exhausted? Think of ways to make daily activities fun together.

quiz_3_feedback_4.eng:
Great idea!

Do you ever feel like you have NO TIME and are exhausted? Try to think of ways to make daily activities fun together.

quiz_3_feedback_5.eng:
Great idea!

Do you ever feel like you have NO TIME and are exhausted? Try to think of ways to make daily activities fun together.
